inventory.commentary: Includes idioms: at_hand, at_the_hand(s)_of, by_hand, in_hand, on_all_hands, on_every_hand, on_hand, on_one's_hands, out_of_hand, to_hand

sense.name: a prehensile forelimb, as a paw or with fingers
sense.examples: The guitarist had large, powerful hands. Three students raised their hands to answer the question. The chimp grabbed the banana in one hand while swinging from a vine with the other. We marveled at the tiny claw-like hands of the T-Rex skeleton in contrast to its huge hind quarters.

sense.name: a worker, e.g., laborer, crew member, specialist
sense.examples: The hired hands eat in the kitchen at their ranch. All hands were called to the fore deck. The director of the lab is calling an all-hands meeting tomorrow at four. The President is calling in his top China hands to deal with this. John is an old hand at billiards.

sense.name: creator or author of something, as a painter, writer, sculptor
sense.examples: Experts believe the two paintings are done by the same hand. He was pleased to see the report reflect his hand in the project. The cavern presented the hand of nature everywhere in the twisting columns and forms of limestone. This collection of anonymous poems is clearly the hand of a master. The hand of an amateur was all over the sloppy burglary of the jewelry store.

sense.name: a member of a bridge card game
sense.examples: We need a fourth hand for our bridge party tonight. The dummy hand usually fetches drinks and snacks for the other players.

sense.name: penmanship or writing style
sense.examples: My hand has become illegible after years of typing at the computer. The letter was addressed in a round, feminine hand.

sense.name: a physical pointer or indicator, as on a clock
sense.examples: What time is it when the little hand is on two and the big hand is on twelve? A digital clock doesn't indicate the time with hands.

sense.name: a figurative position in relation to other positions, as in arguments
sense.examples: On the one hand, we would enjoy the weather in California, on the other we'd spend a fortune on housing. There were protests on all hands at the town meeting about banning dogs from the conservation land.

sense.name: applause, congratulatory gesture
sense.examples: Let's give the students a hand for their great job. The audience gave the comedian a big hand as he walked off stage.

sense.name: pledge, as in a marriage proposal
sense.examples: The prince asked for her hand in marriage. She wouldn't accept the prince's hand, but instead eloped with the shoemaker.

sense.name: a physical blow or punch
sense.examples: That boxer has a dangerous left hand. The defendant maintains he never laid a hand on the plaintiff.

sense.name: give assistance or aid
sense.examples: The storm victims could use a helping hand right now. John has offered to lend us a hand moving next week. They'll need a hand with that new project if you have some spare time.

sense.name: gain control or possession
sense.examples: The documents have fallen into enemy hands. You need to take the upper hand with that spirited stallion. Their firm will have the upper hand in these negotiations.

sense.name: aptitude or ability
sense.examples: I decided to try my hand at kite surfing. Bob decided to try his hand at running a business.

sense.name: a unit of length, about 4 inches
sense.examples: The big draft horse stood 20 hands high. I'd say that filly is about 16 hands.

sense.name: a collection of cards a player holds in a card game
sense.examples: My last hand contained two pairs and a seven. John laid out his winning hand for all to see. That firm's winning hand this year was a bold and innovative marketing strategy. (metaphoric)

sense.name: a unit of game play
sense.examples: We played three hands of poker before Bob joined the game. I think you folded too soon in the last hand. This bridge hand Mary is sitting out as the dummy.

sense.name: a cluster of leaves, as banana or tobacco
sense.examples: The auctioneer lifted hands of tobacco onto the scale to be weighed. The man was carrying about twenty hands of bananas on his donkey.

sense.name: near or within reach, current
sense.examples: Let's deal with the business at hand before considering the new proposal. I'll make dinner with whatever is at hand in the pantry.

sense.name: through the action of
sense.examples: The temple was destroyed at the hands of the enemy.

sense.name: performed manually, not by machine or remote process
sense.examples: Her silk wedding gown was sewn entirely by hand. The documents containing state secrets were only delivered by hand., not through the mail.

sense.name: in one's possession or control
sense.examples: I have the agreement in hand. She doesn't seem to have those dogs in hand very well.

sense.name: everywhere
sense.examples: There were pitfalls facing us on every hand.

sense.name: available, or in present possession
sense.examples: I always keep tomato paste and dried pasta on hand. They are keeping some extra officers on hand for the after-game celebrations. Our VP was not on hand for the meeting this morning.

sense.name: in one's possession
sense.examples: They seem to have a lot of time on their hands. The regime will have a lot of blood on its hands for these actions.

sense.name: out of control
sense.examples: Things have gotten a bit out of hand in the spot energy markets. The party got out of hand last night.
